summary: Gaeton Fonzi was a staff member of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). The documents indicate that in May 1978, Fonzi, along with Albert Gonzales, visited Guayaquil and Caracas as part of the HSCA's investigation. One cable discusses the CIA's awareness of their upcoming visit and requests guidance on potential contact. Another cable from 1995 mentions a meeting in Rio de Janeiro involving Cuban CI officers and alleged CIA officers, focusing on reviewing the JFK assassination, although Fonzi's direct involvement in this meeting is not specified, it highlights the continued interest in the JFK assassination and related investigations.
significance: Gaeton Fonzi's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his role as a staff member of the HSCA, which was tasked with investigating the assassination. His visits to Guayaquil and Caracas as part of the HSCA investigation suggest his involvement in gathering information and potentially interviewing individuals related to the assassination.
